docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The statement by officials that a 31-year-old California prisoner given a heart transplant was handled as any other patient would have been is incorrect (news article, Jan. 31). The inmate was actually treated better than some law-abiding patients who are denied heart transplants because of inadequate insurance. There is something intuitively very wrong with this situation. The article cited a 1976 United States Supreme Court ruling that prisoners must receive ''adequate medical care.'' Are there any limits to the court's mandate? Should it include assisted reproductive technology for infertile inmates? Should a convicted serial murderer receive the limited resource of a human heart?

headline.main: Heal the Prisoners, And the Rest of Us

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth Prager letter says all Americans should be entitled to kind of medical care extended to California prisoner who had heart transplant (Jan 31 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: They complained of the mind-numbing 21 steps required to get a contract approved. They complained of payments delayed for months, even years. They complained of being forced to get emergency loans. They even complained of payless paydays. More than 200 people from local nonprofit groups filled an auditorium here today to demand that fiscally battered Nassau County change how it handles millions of dollars in grants. Their programs involve child care, domestic violence, mental health, homelessness, substance abuse, immigrants, invalids, the young and the aged.

headline.main: Nonprofits Say Nassau's Grant Process Needs Fixing

docs.abstract: Nonprofit groups complain about arcane process of getting grant money in Nassau County, NY; many working for nonprofit agencies have gone without getting paid and say it can take two or three years for contract approval; County Executive Thomas Suozzi vows to reform system (M)
docs.snippet: They complained of the mind-numbing 21 steps required to get a contract approved. They complained of payments delayed for months, even years. They complained of being forced to get emergency loans. They even complained of payless paydays.    More...

docs.lead_paragraph: The former head of Hale House, the Harlem children's shelter, has been told to expect to be arrested today on charges stemming from the state attorney general's investigation of financial irregularities at the charity, several people with direct knowledge of the investigation said. The exact nature of the charges against the shelter's deposed president, Lorraine E. Hale, 75, could not be learned last night, but they are expected to involve the allegations of financial mismanagement that Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has been examining for months. Officials with Mr. Spitzer's office refused to discuss the investigation yesterday.

headline.main: Arrest Is Expected Today For Ex-Head of Hale House

docs.abstract: Lorraine E Hale, former head of Harlem children's shelter Hale House, has been told to expect to be arrested on charges stemming from Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's investigation of financial irregularities (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They tried to camouflage the action. Bush administration officials presented it as an altruistic attempt to bring badly needed health care benefits to low-income pregnant women. It was actually a guerrilla attack on abortion rights. Alarm bells automatically go off when this administration claims to be helping the financially disadvantaged. So you knew something had to be up when the Department of Health and Human Services announced last week that it had figured out a way to provide prenatal care to low-income women who might not otherwise be eligible.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says rules change by Health and Human Services Dept, broadening definition of 'child' to include fetuses, so they would be eligible for health coverage, is political move; calls it message to rightwingers of Republican Party that Bush administration is committed to undermining abortion rights; says if administration truly wants to do something about extending health benefits to children, it could start with 11 million children currently without health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers have offered a compromise bill requiring health insurers to cover contraceptives, winning the support of birth control advocates and closing much of the gap between their position and the Democrats'. But a key Democratic legislator remains dissatisfied with a provision in the Republican bill that would allow insurers to charge deductibles for mammograms, and cast doubt on whether the Democrat-controlled Assembly would accept the bill. The dispute has been one of the most intractable in the State Capitol in recent years and has become the central issue in a hard-fought campaign for a State Senate seat from Manhattan.

headline.main: Albany Bill Would Cover Birth Control

docs.abstract: New York's Republican lawmakers offer compromise bill requiring health insurers to cover contraceptives, but Democrats are dissatisfied with provision that would allow insurers to charge deductibles for mammograms; shift by Republican leaders represents their most significant compromise in four years; it has become central issue in race between Liz Krueger and John Ravitz for vacant Senate seat representing East Side of Manhattan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In its glory days, WebMD attracted strategic partners like Microsoft, the News Corporation and DuPont and bought dozens of electronic and online health care companies with highflying WebMD stock. Entranced by those deals and the company's well-publicized dream of hooking up all the players in health care, investors pushed the share price of Healtheon/WebMD, as it was then called, to $126.1875 in May 1999. The bubble popped in 2000, and by last September the shares fell as low as $3.22.

headline.main: Market Place; WebMD Is Somewhat Stronger After Therapy

docs.abstract: Market Place column on outlook for WebMD, leading health care consumer Internet portal, whose stock plunged when Internet bubble burst in 2000; company is making recovery of sorts after 15 months of turnaround therapy under leadership of Martin J Wygod, who took over from company's founders; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Across-the-board budget cuts, the layoff of more than 1,000 state workers and a freeze in state aid to New Jersey cities and towns announced during Gov. James E. McGreevey's first two weeks on the job have suggested that much of his first year in office will be defined by the state deficit. But despite all the publicity that Mr. McGreevey's belt-tightening has generated, the cuts announced so far will save less than $200 million -- roughly one-fifteenth of the deficit he must eliminate by June 30.

headline.main: McGreevey Struggles to Cope With a Budget Shortfall He Inherited

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov James McGreevey will face three uncomfortable and politically volatile options in order to cope with budget shortfall: increased borrowing, increased taxes or huge layoffs and program cuts; he has declined to discuss details of his plan prior to addressing joint session of State Legislature on Feb 11; it is likely that he will tap reserve funds to close budget gap for current fiscal year, however use of one-shot solutions now still leaves up to $6 billion shortfall in next fiscal year; during campaign, McGreevey promised not to raise taxes, but now says he meant only income and sales taxes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Across-the-board budget cuts, the layoff of more than 1,000 state workers and a freeze in state aid to New Jersey cities and towns announced during Gov. James E. McGreevey's first two weeks on the job have suggested that much of his first year in...

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics, which offers guidance to parents on child-rearing issues from spanking to nutrition, is announcing its support today for the right of gay men and lesbians to adopt their partners' children. ''Children who are born to or adopted by one member of a same-sex couple deserve the security of two legally recognized parents,'' the academy says in a policy statement published in its scientific journal, Pediatrics.

headline.main: Group Wants Gays to Have Right to Adopt a Partner's Child

docs.abstract: American Academy of Pediatrics says it will support right of gay men and lesbians to adopt their partners' children; says most studies over past two decades indicate children of gay or lesbian parents are as well adjusted socially and psychologically as those of heterosexual parents; experts say endorsement is likely to carry weight in courts and legislatures because group, which represents 55,000 pediatricians, enjoys wide respect; three states currently ban such adoptions, while seven and Washington (DC) permit them by law or court ruling; otherwise, legal status of such adoptions varies widely; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-10 Muted Mood for a Meeting Accustomed to Celebrating This year, the world's most powerful policy makers and entrepreneurs, who in past years gathered at the World Economic Conference to promote the Internet revolution, are focused on their vulnerabilities. 1 Foreign economists are much less optimistic than their American counterparts about what is ahead for the United States economy. 16
